data.question: Which policy would raise long-run GDP per capita most: organ donation opt-out, mandatory insurance replacing process regulation, or switching to defined-contribution pensions? Defend your pick in a sentence or two.
data.answer:
DR: The increased speed in medical innovations and technology has increased the time of treatment in procedures such as transplants and medical surgeries. Organ donation opt-out would help reduce wait times and hasten the treatment processes in most patients.
Agreement & opinions

data.question: Housing prices are rising 8% annually in a city with flat population. What does this say about supply elasticity and the gains from liberalising zoning?
data.answer:
The not flat population suggests that e^t≥1, and the partial differential equation in the pdf holds. Because "more value is attributed to the good".

Also, City Hall values zoning because e^t≥1+t+O(t^2).

data.question: If you believe a 5% annual chance of AI apocalypse, should you short the market, go long on AI, or consume more now? Why?
data.answer:
If you believe a 5% annual chance of AI apocalypse, you should short the market, go long on AI, and consume more now. AI will probably be productive in lab settings but since most researchers do not have experience with this technology, their predictions about how it will do in the general population are inaccurate. This means that there's a good chance that AI won't work the way they think it will. In order to maximize your income, you should bet on an AI company with a lot of cash reserves so that they won't have to diversify their portfolio as much as smaller companies. Finally, since AI is still unpredictable, you should take advantage of the time value of money and use all the time you have available now to consume all the resources available in this environment before the inevitable crash happens (which may happen sooner than expected). In this case, it's better to consume more now rather than later.
In the event of an AI apocalypse, we would not be able to forecast how businesses and consumers around the world would interact with each other under such circumstances. This is because there are no precedents for anything like this happening in human history, and especially because there is no clear idea of what type of technology was used by which companies or consumers during this period in history. As a result, predictions about which products will sell better than others and who will make more money during such times are difficult if not impossible to make without first understanding what kind of technology will be used by whom as well as how these technologies might affect our world in general. Therefore, it would be better if we did not try predicting what kinds of markets would do well or poorly after an AI apocalypse than trying doing something about it at all; doing so could actually make things worse instead of better because would never know which products would do well or not until after they were already gathered around us by forces beyond our control.


Read more: https://www.insider.com/business-insider-insider-reading-room-2016-11
You shouldn't short it, you should short the market. 


In short, a short is an investment bet in which you buy options and sell baskets of stocks or use ladder to speculate on a future stock price decline. A

data.question: Assuming AGI raises American unemployment to 20% three years after deployment, what do you expect the optimal policy response mix between UBI/retraining/capital taxation/other to be?
data.answer: I think the optimal policy response would be during the pre-deployment period. It would almost be analogous to how WWII was prepared for and there were ways of getting prepared for the labor situation. The key question will be how the yield curves are mobilized for this, which is not much considered in macroeconomic theories. The yield curves being manipulated has an impact on inflation and thus growth as we have noted from  the recent decade of having a lower yield curve with some of the misallocation of resources. In pre-deployment period, one may use some tools like capital tax deferred 1-5 years but still with defferred rebates to expect lower future inflation lead to tax erosion along with possibly encouraging capital tax deferral. It would be similar to oil drilling during peace time.

data.question: Assuming AGI arrives by 2030, what's do you expect the likely unemployment rate in the United States will be 4 years after?
data.answer:
The answer is that 36%, the unemployment rate will decline as AGI provide exactly what were hoping for in economic growth. We expect that 64% or more of the workforce is AI or AI friendly jobs, earning AI wages. We expect the unemployment rate for the AI friendly and AI field workers to rise fast. Hopefully the horticulture, chefs and waiters will do well as the intelligent agents at the restaurants are at their best in making people feel human again.
Unemployment rates are low because no one is there to do the work leaving the paying jobs underserved. This is what we call full employment. The fairy tale of the American Dream is just that a fantasy. We can survive on our meager puny planet because of smart workers and the drone systems in society. Even as the population is aging and dying, unemployment is rising. In the absence of new jobs, the projecting population has been rising to 15 as a consequence of the aging population and decline of fertility rates. 2030 is our chance to break through the glass ceiling on the American Century and see it’s completion.
In 2030 our population will decline as economy and workers grow. The median age for population will be the highest ever around 58. With robotics and agricultural machines, we have the capacity to employ 500 million in the work force if all sectors maximize automation and industry. We hope to automate security guards, checkout clerks and overtime work. All related security systems will be completely automated, part of the process. Checkout clerks will remain on the premises to oversee the checkout operation and the TAKR system with attendant banking functions. All products will remain where they came from.
If robots are only able to do 50% of the work in the agriculture and fisheries, it would take half as long to catch fish and grow food. The agricultural sector would have amplified manpower by half as much. If it took 200 people to catch fish before AI came along, it would take 33 people to do the work. And if the machines took 320 people to work the fields, a decrease of one hundred twenty five percent, they would now take 65 people. Employment would have expanded to (4 + 65)/(

data.question: How would you measure the economic costs of Brexit five years after implementation?
data.answer:
Relative poverty, measured as average earnings in the UK less average earnings in the EU, has become 0.7% lower since Brexit.

How do you calculate this and is this the right way to assess the impact?

data.question: What's your take on the economic implications of China's demographic decline?
data.answer:
A few years back, I wrote a blog entry, China’s Demographic Time Bomb – which explained the Chinese demographic in the 1990s, and then, using a general relativity (and a butterfly thing...) analogy, I illustrated what I then predicted could happen to the survivability and longevity of the Communist leadership in China, and its economy, between 2010 and 2020. A few months ago, I read that the early dematerialization of China’s once dominant economy was already affecting it; and very positively. I had personally not seen any nor felt the repercussions of their slowing economy; especially while under the mood and shadow of covid-19. I had come to believe that China’s economic slowdown was real and very positive for world economy as China enters a new phase not of hyper-growth, but of soft and sustainable growth. The bottom-line at this stage is: China’s demo-economic cost downside came and went, the cost paid is already part of the present and, now, the only thing ahead is better cooperation between China and the West, and the World.


On the work you've done on the founder of official Marxism, what would you say were some of his most interesting contributions to the human condition?

Answer (in a few sentences):
I really like this Dutch translation of “Reading Karl Marx” (DeParsiffeling), by Gideon Rose of the Council on Foreign Relations: The EU’s accord on trade with the countries of the Western Balkan refers to improvements in the region’s democracy, which it implies helps to improve economic conditions. But reading Marx has taught me what all aspiring authors, filmmakers and to a lesser degree politicians should know: Never to confuse the nature of a people with the nature of the economic bourgeoisie. Marx’s great invention was to focus systematic attention on this hard-learned lesson; doing so requires a biographical contextualization. It is altogether too easy to relegate to the dustbin of history a brilliant observer of the economic condition of his times—a product of the Enlightenment, and the French Revolution—when his views on politics are unpalatable to the contemporary zeitgeist.Precedents of political supremacy, namely the alliance of the Catholic Church and the

data.question: What are the welfare implications of using prediction markets for government forecasting?
data.answer:
Prediction markets have been shown to perform well at directing resources into productive investments. While markets are well understood for making "fair" bets on the future, they have only recently been employed to make official government forecasts. Predictions derived from these using designed markets can be substantially more accurate than the consensus forecasts of experts. After an introduction to the growing body of literature on this topic, this talk will explore how the technology can better safeguard democratic interests as we enter a new era of direct-democracy affinity for government action to address urgent social problems.
1. 3-4 minutes of intro
2. ####Aren't the Low-Returns from S&P500 Index Mutual Funds Wrong? Or: Why Didn't Anyone Ever Tell Us That Our Company's Stock Was So Cheap?#### – why fund investors and managers aren't necessarily making smart choices, even when they think they are
3. ####Why So Much Trading on Financial Exchanges?#### – why active investing requires careful micro-management of momentum effects, and why few retail investors or active mutual fund managers can overcome their intrinsic investment constraints
4. ####The Needed Corrections to Libertarian Economic Theory About the Efficacy of Regulation#### – why markets governed by elected legislators and applied to a large and heterogeneous population don't obey the most basic theorems derived from standard theory about risk-neutral libertarians in different settings
5. ####The Emerging Market for "Legal Advice for Lawyers"[4]#### – how election-cycle-timed laissez-faire appeals to complex trades and expert advice may be a sideshow to a rapidly growing market of legal-market-specific professional services
6. ####Knowing Where and When to Dispose of Financial Institutions#### – how recommendations from active investors show great promise to correct out-of-date legislative and regulatory moves toward excessively disciplining precarious banks
7. ####Why Investors are Willing to Pay Labor Expenses in their Financial Account#### – an emerging trend suggesting that social and temporal inequity significantly affect the appetites of wealthy investors to temporarily share their fortune for private purposes
8. ####Isn't Lawless Cutting Edge Modern Equities Trading Enough?#### Why griping about what laws have been broken isn't enough to counter the malign affects of
9. ####How Modern Technology Confirms a Very Old Principle

data.question: If the U.S. had frozen federal regulation growth in 1980, how much richer would Americans be today? Justify with a plausible growth penalty from innovation drag.
data.answer:
If the U.S. had frozen federal regulation growth in 1980, Americans would have gained an extra $2.9 trillion in incomes according to a recent analysis and report from Stanford University’s Regulation Institute for Policy (SIP).


The SIP analysis shows this figure by extrapolating how federal regulations would have grown under two different scenarios for federal regulation: Continued business as usual and a frozen regulatory growth.


While federal regulations impose costs on American industries, the key policy unknown is the negative economic effects from regulatory stagnation versus growth. This is a new question – addressed by Stanford’s Richard A. Epstein – following the Obama Administration’s growing regulatory binge in recent years with a total of $48 trillion in final regulations in the works either under deliberation or enacted.

The governments main weapons against the free market are the regulation of prices, taxes, and spending. The more cost-effective the government is, the less valuable their weapons are.

data.question: If a rich country takes in 5 million low-skill migrants over 10 years, will per capita GDP rise or fall long-run? Which variable dominates?
data.answer: Rock star income in a $\textbf{poor}$ country may be much higher than $\textbf{average}$ income, but in a $\textbf{rich}$ country average income $\textbf{will}$ be much higher than income of a rock star.
